summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against defendant Javier Chandler for second-degree murder in February 2016.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in New York, alleges that, on February 22, 2016, Appellant, then a resident of Escambia County, Florida, engaged in a series of unprovoked confrontations with a man who claimed he had just purchased a gun for him.  According to the complaint, the two men had been childhood friends and, on the day of the alleged shooting, had been neighbors since childhood.  As alleged in the SEC's Complaint, however, the defendants had been friends since childhood, but had been estranged from each other for years.  Appellantly, as alleged, when confronted by a group of brawlers who confronted him, he allegedly replied, "I should have killed you."  The complaint further alleges that Appelant, a few years' Chandler's junior, followed him into the house and demanded to know where his new gun was.  He allegedly told the man that he did not want to fight with him because he wanted to make a small profit when he asked him to give him his gun.  In addition, the complaint alleges that the defendant confronted the man with a gun and demanded that he "change his mind," which he did, and confronted him with the gun, which he took out of his pocket and fired at the man, causing him to fall to the ground.  After the initial round of gunfire, the defendant shot the man in the head and died at the scene.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the SEC, Chandler consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, a civil penalty, and an officer-and-director bar.  On May 2, 2018, the Honorable Judge Paul G. Donahue entered a judgment permanently enjoining him from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, ordering him to disgorge his ill will, hatred, spite, and evil intent, and to pay civil penalties of $50,000 and $75,000, respectively.   The court also ordered him to surrender his passport and to be barred from associating with any third- or fourth-party dealers in the United States.  To settle his case, the court granted the court's motion for a preliminary injunction against future violations, and ordered him
